visuals.title: Bacteria
visuals.description:
Clicking adds new bacteria to the playground. These are babies at first, but slowly reach maturity and finaly die of age.
They spend their lives by moving arround on the playground. If two adult bacteria of different sex meet they have a child.
Ill bacteria age faster and pass the illnes to their children.

Colors:
turquoise := male baby bacteria
yellow := female baby bacteria
blue := male mature bacteria
red := female mature bacteria
purple := ill, male mature bacteria
pink := ill, female mature bacteria

left mouse button := add bacteria
right mouse button := add ill bacteria

visuals.title: Obj viewer
visuals.description:
Reads data from an obj format and displays it.

An obj format is a generic format used by most 3d software packages to describe a mesh. In fact, this model was exported out from Maya.

There's so much more to be done with this, but here's a start!

Controls:
    - Drag left-click to rotate camera.
    - Drag middle-click to move camera.
    - Drag right-click to zoom.
    - E to toggle edges.
    - P to toggle points.
    - F to toggle faces.

visuals.title: USphHarmonics01
visuals.description:
Simple implementation of the well-known series of wave functions known as spherical harmonics, which are defined in spherical coordinates and thus define 3D volumes. 

This sketch demonstrates a possible way to morph between  two UGeometry geometries, provided that the two objects have the same number of faces.

Written using Paul Bourke's code as a reference:
http://paulbourke.net/geometry/sphericalh/

(Part of my series of reference implementations of classic algorithms...)

visuals.title: Kinect 3D scanner
visuals.description:
Simple 3D scanner using the Kinect.

Doesn't work in the browser. You need a Kinect to run it and the controlP5 (version controlP5_1.5.1), hemesh and simple-openni libraries installed. 
 
Select the scanner area with the controls and press the "take scan" button to capture the 3D points inside the box. A mesh is created with the Hemesh library and saved in the sketch directory. The colors of the mesh faces are saved in a different file. Press the "take scan" button again to take more scans. 
 
Use http://www.openprocessing.org/sketch/62533 to read and represent the mesh.

visuals.title: Basic Drawing Pad
visuals.description:
The gui offers a few basic colors to pick from without bothering to deal with the sliders, there's also a few basic brush widths to pick from.  However if you want to try them out, each slider alters a certain variable that makes up the color. Also, for those of you that actually made a file for this, you can save the pictures you create with the save button.

Keyboard Shortcuts:
e - Increases brush width
q - Decreases brush width
z - Clears the canvas
c - Color picker 
r  - Increases the red value
t -  Decreases the red value
b - Increases the blue value
n - Decreases the blue value

visuals.title: Fireflies Synchronization
visuals.description:
This is a Processing sketch to simulate the way fireflies synchronize with one another. Each of of the circles represents a single firefly and when another firefly on the screen flashes white, or "fires", the firefly will try and catch up to the firefly that just fired. The world makes many assumptions, so here is a list of some of them:
1) Every firefly can see every other firefly and has 20/20 vision
2) Every firefly starts with the same period
3) Every firefly is influenced additively or linearly by the number of flies firing

visuals.title: Tiny Fibonacci Sphere v2.0
visuals.description:
A fast method of producing an arbitrary number of equally distributed points around a sphere. This is accomplished by drawing a fibonacci spiral (similar to sunflower seed pattern) that maintains constant surface area.

n = number of points
phi = (sqrt(5)+1)/2 - 1
ga = PHI * PI

for each point i (1..n)
longitude = ga*i
latitude = asin(-1 + 2*i/n)

As written, the sketch constantly adds new points to the sphere. Click to toggle this feature, so you can examine the point distribution.

Movement mode 3 = All fish align along a radial vector field

visuals.title: Nested Stochastic Cellular Automaton
visuals.description: Elementary cellular automaton with stochastic extension. This means that there is not necesserily ony one but multiple rulesets for state transitions where each ruleset has a stochastic  distribution (some rulesets are more likely to be chosen). A nested CA might be created for each cell with state '0' (with different rulesets and maybe bigger than the original cell). Press mouse to create new drawing.
visuals.instructions: Press mouse to create new drawing.

visuals.title: Circular Network 2
visuals.description:
The program reads in .txt files and sorts nodes according to their sizes. The largest node is at 12'o clock position and the sizes decrease clockwise.

Color can represent another dimension of information, right now they represent the same information as size does. 

Red nodes always have their names displayed and other nodes display their names if you place your mouse over them.

You can adjust the THRESHOLD variable to display more edges. Most of the edges are 100% transparent now.

Thanks and enjoy! I will add some comments to my codes when I have time.

The code is relatively easy to figure out, it's a particle system. Enjoy.

Paints an image with strokes that are rotated by a flow field driven from noise.

  - Press any key to save the canvas to a jpg.

- "c" key: generate new colors
- "1" to "4" keys: apply preset values
- left click: generate a random attractor

visuals.title: Tweets of the world
visuals.description:
This is an experiment based on random tweets I gathered through Twitter's API https://dev.twitter.com/docs/api/1/get/statuses/sample

controls: 
- left click: zoom in
- right click: zoom out
- drag the map once zoomed in
- mouse overs the dots: display the tweets' message and country

When translating this sketch from 'regular' Processing to ProcessingJS, I had many issues, including:
- map() does not work (!?)
- PGraphics.clear() does not work (!?)
- mouseDragged() is called as soon as mousePressed is called (!?)
- simple loops such as for(Tweet tweet in tweets) don't work (!?)

visuals.title: Tweets of the 3D world
visuals.description:
This is a port of my previous 2D sketch towards a 3D view. Only works on Chrome online.

controls:
- drag the mouse to rotate the Earth
- mouse over the tweets to display their message/country
- mouse wheel should zoom in/out, but if not you can press up/down keys

Once again, it is very limited by Processing JS... It turns out that:
- no fill() can be used in the whole code, otherwise the texture shall apply it as well no matter what
- hint(DISABLE_DEPTH_TEST) also messes with the texture rendering, it is unusable in my case. This leads to a bad text display, I know ^^

Edit: had to remove the sounds, as they do not work anymore. Under investigation.

Now blow the meteors away!
